Posts.Content: tadpole wrote: Hello all, I just wanted to let you know how things are with me.  I am now in a hospice; been here for just about two weeks.  I am very well taken care of, and am able to escape for short day trips home to see pets and take care of things.  It seems like it's the darned ol' liver; if you look at me sideways, I look like a cross between Alfred Hitchcock and a really fat penguin.   I'd like to thank you all for for your contributions to my small request for songs.  They really helped me through an awful week, during which I found out that I was also dealing with a bowel infection. I'll try to check in (or have my son check in for me) during the next few weeks for a quick update but will probably be closing up the account soon. Best of luck in all your various journeys. Courage is the art of being the only one who knows you're scared to death - Earl Wilson Dx 9/6/2006, IDC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 7/20 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Message from Tadpole tadpole pajim

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2013 06:56AM tadpole wrote: What a beautiful song! Love really is what it's all about, isn't it? You guys are awesome! I have already surpassed my expected "expiration" date, so maybe will pop in again sometime......

Posts.Title: Message from Tadpole tadpole pajim

Posts.Content: tadpole wrote: Hi Ladies.  I just got out of the hospital with a diagnosis of cancer of the meninges.  Went in with a numb chin, and after a kazillion tests, came out with a numb soul.  Evidently it "changes my prognosis considerably".  We may be talking weeks, or a few months, they say. So now I'm left up in the air until Aug. 5, 'cause the doctors are on vacation, to find out what's next.  (None of it good, I'm thinking).  I soooooo want to see my grandchild born this Dec., but was told to talk to my family, basically to get my affairs in order.  (They already are). Anyone have/had experience with this, or know someone else who has?  In the past four weeks, I have had three friends die of cancer, one a very close friend who died within a month of being diagnosed, and I'm so frickin' tired of this sneaky ba***rd disease. It's been seven years, and I thought I was doing pretty good.  I'm just sad, is all. Courage is the art of being the only one who knows you're scared to death - Earl Wilson Dx 9/6/2006, IDC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 7/20 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Leptominingeal carcinoma tadpole lulu89

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2013 07:23AM tadpole wrote: Thanks, everybody, for your good wishes. I came home from the hospital Thursday and ended up being re-admitted Friday with a high fever.  Just got home last night.  I am SO not impressed with hospitals - only once got my Xeloda on time even when I reminded the nurses, twice it was the wrong dose, I was actually told by one nurse not to complain, I was lucky I got it when I did, most nurses would not speak English to me (or could not, I don't know). Yes, I speak French but when you feel like crap and have to translate it's an extra stress. At one point I was on a heart monitor and wanted to go pee and the nurse said she didn't have time to unhook me, (which takes all of one minute), I would just have to wait, so I did it myself. Yes, I'm sure everyone's busy and overworked, but where is the compassion, the bedside manner anymore?  When I trained as a nursing assistant years ago things sure were different. Anyway, I'm sure everybody here is quite familiar with how hospitals can be.  We have to tell the kids this weekend, and my brothers and their wives want to come visit, but I don't want to see anyone till I can get my head around this a bit, and I'm too tired to entertain and no appetite to eat. Hope they understand, but I can't make it easy for other people anymore - the well has run dry. So, I'll know more next Monday and will update. Take care, everybody.
Posts.Title: Leptominingeal carcinoma tadpole lulu89

Posts.Content: May 5, 2013 09:14PM tadpole wrote: A close friend said to me the other day - "I don't know if it's from getting older, or chemo brain, but you seem a lot less tolerant and more snippy (read cranky) lately".  Um, really?????  I wonder why?  Maybe it's got something to do with "not suffering fools gladly"?
